text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then uses the stairs for the remaining floors.
However, when it's raining or when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I need to figure out why this man takes the elevator down every morning to the ground floor, but when he comes back in the evening, he goes to the 7th floor and then uses the stairs.
And when it's raining or there are other people in the elevator, he goes all the way up to the 10th floor.
Hmm, that's a bit confusing.
Let me try to break it down.
First, he lives on the 10th floor.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor.
That makes sense because he's going to work, so he probably doesn't want to climb up and down the stairs every day.
The elevator is faster and more convenient.
In the evening, when he comes back, he takes the elevator up to the 7th floor and then uses the stairs for the remaining floors.
So from 7th to 10th, that's 3 floors.
Maybe he does this because he doesn't want to wait for the elevator when he's in a hurry to get home, or maybe he prefers the stairs for some reason.

But why 7th floor specifically?

Now, the interesting part is when it's raining or when there are other people in the elevator.
In those cases, he goes directly to the 10th floor.
So, when it's raining, he takes the elevator all the way up.
Similarly, if there are people in the elevator, he doesn't get off at the 7th floor; he stays until the 10th.
Wait a minute, maybe it has to do with the elevator's behavior.
Perhaps when it's raining, the elevator doesn't stop at certain floors, or maybe he prefers not to get wet by taking the stairs.
But then, when there are other people in the elevator, he stays until the 10th floor.
Maybe he doesn't want to wait for the elevator to come back down, so he just goes all the way up when there are people already in it.
Alternatively, maybe the elevator has a rule where it only stops at certain floors, especially during bad weather.
So when it's raining, the elevator might not stop at the 7th floor, or he might prefer to avoid the stairs because of the rain.
So he takes the elevator all the way up instead.
But why does he take the elevator to the 7th floor normally? Maybe because from 7th to 10th, it's quicker by stairs, and he doesn't want to wait for the elevator to come back up.
Or perhaps the elevator only goes to the 7th floor, and he has to switch to stairs after that.
Wait, another angle: maybe the building's elevator has a limitation.

For example, in the morning, he takes the elevator down, but in the evening, he can't get all the way to the 10th floor because the elevator is either busy or slow, so he gets off at the 7th and uses stairs.
But when it's raining, the elevator is more reliable or faster, so he takes it all the way.
Similarly, if there are other people in the elevator, he stays because he doesn't want to wait for the next one.
Alternatively, maybe the man has a preference for the stairs when it's not raining or when the elevator is less crowded.
So he takes the elevator down in the morning because he's in a hurry, and in the evening, he uses the stairs from 7th to 10th because he prefers the stairs.
But when it's raining, he uses the elevator because the stairs might be slippery or he doesn't want to get wet, hence taking the elevator all the way up.

Similarly, when there are other people in the elevator, he might not want to stop at the 7th floor because he doesn't want to hold up the elevator or because he prefers not to wait for it to come back down.
So he just goes all the way up.

Putting it all together, it seems like the man uses the elevator in the morning because it's faster, and in the evening, he switches to stairs for the last few floors unless there's a reason not to, like rain or crowded elevator, in which case he takes the elevator all the way.

</think>

The man takes the elevator down in the morning because it's faster.
In the evening, he takes the stairs from the 7th to the 10th floor because he prefers them.
However, when it's raining or the elevator is busy with others, he takes the elevator all the way up to avoid the stairs' hazards or waiting.
